title: Materials Up On Trade-Deal Hopes — Materials Roundup
text:
Producers of metals and other raw materials recouped Tuesday's losses as market expectations for a trade deal swung back into optimistic territory.

Chinese officials have reportedly expressed a willingness to strike a limited agreement with the U.S., despite objections to the U.S. decision to black-list 28 more companies and state organizations. On Tuesday, commodity and stock prices fell sharply because of fears the blacklist would derail talks due to commence Thursday.

Gold futures, used by investors as a safe haven at times when economic and market risks are elevated, rose slightly.

Cocoa futures prices have climbed 18% in London since Aug. 29, as traders contend with a new method for pricing African exports designed to alleviate poverty in Ivory Coast and Ghana, two of the world's largest growers of the chocolate ingredient, as reported earlier.

One brokerage said the cardboard business is exhibiting unexpected strength. "While macro conditions are subdued and economic uncertainty is high, containerboard data shows resilience and is generally constructive," said analysts at brokerage Credit Suisse, in a note to clients. European containerboard shipments have "reaccelerated, " while "production discipline" has offset uneven demand in the U.S., the Credit Suisse analysts said.
